Cuerpo: Date: Tue, 26 Nov 1996 18:59:51 GMT Server: Apache/1.0.5 Content-type: text/html Content-length: 2456 Last-modified: Mon, 21 Oct 1996 03:03:38 GMT Comp 50 / Fall 96 -- Computing on the Internet Comp 50 / Fall 96 -- Computing on the Internet This course is being designed as a replacement for COMP 5 (Survey of Computer Science). The overall goal of the course is to familiarize students with use of the Internet and to give them an understanding of the underlying computational methods that are involved. Topics covered include: Using a Unix computer system such as emerald. What's going on behind the scenes:  the file system, the shell, transmission of I/O streams through communication equipment. Naming schemes:  IP addresses, domain names, pathnames, URLs. The nature of client/server computing. Email: how it is formatted and handled. How to read an email header. Using browsers. The HTML language for Web pages. Syntax. Tags for linking to other documents. Binary, hex, and octal numeration; the Ascii code. Representational methods for numbers, messages, text, and images. Measuring the size of a block of information. Data compression. Encryption of information. Private key systems. Public key systems. David Krumme krumme@cs.tufts.edu
